p: Instead of treatment with glycosidases, alkaline hydrolysis can be used to convert lignan glucosides to aglycons. Various conditions for alkaline hydrolysis have been reported in literature, such as refluxing with 1 M potassium hydroxide in ethanol [ 142], treatment with 9 M sodium hydroxide in water at room temperature overnight [ 143], and treatment with sodium methoxide in pure methanol (3 h at 40 °C with sonication) [ 104]. A combination of alkaline hydrolysis (0.3 M NaOH in 70% methanol, incubated for 1 h at 60 °C) with a subsequent enzymatic hydrolysis using β-glucuronidase/sulfatase from Helix pomatia has also been used [ 144]. Secoisolariciresinol diglucoside was hydrolyzed successfully by incubation with 1 M sodium or potassium hydroxide for 4 to 24 h at room temperature [ 145].
